content:
衛生福利部民國107年7月20日 衛部秘字第1072161286號通知單註銷密等
and the National Shigella Centres. It should be emphasized, however, that the immediat outlook and preoccupations of the International Centres are somewhat different from those of the National Centros, in that the International Centres, as at present . constituted, concentrate on the tax nomic component, (n), of their two-fold purpose while The National Centres are immediately concerned not only with this aspect but also with component (b), namely, the epidemiological and public health Implications of their · laboratory studies. The International Centros' taxonomie studies, (a), are of a complex techincal nature and must be carried out by specialized personnel within the limited circumference of a microbiological science, without any immediate epidemiological orientation to those studies. That is to say, their microbiological and taxonomic studies must be of the highest competence at the purely laboratory level, and any criticism that such work is too academic to justify direct support by WHO is answerable by the contention that microbiological and taxonomic studies for part of the essent nh raw material for epidemiolo ical studies, and the better the quality of the row material the moro refined ond the more serviere In the final product will be.
The functions and working relationships of the International Centres with the National Centres may perhaps be further clarified us follows. Suppose un outbreak of dysentery or food poisoning to occur in a particular country. Appropriate units of the country's health services, together with its National Shigella or Salmonella Centre, would then be responsible for isolating the causative organism and identifying it as far as they are able to do so. In making this identification the National Centre would be assisted by materials (sora and bacterial cultures) and advice from the 1 International Centre; and if the organism is of a rare or anomalous type it would be despatched to the International Centre for identification. As for the epidemiological and public health aspects of the out reak, it would, of course, again be the responsibility of the country's own health services to carry out the necessary investigations and action, but in the execution of those particular functions the National Centre ight receive less direct assistance from the International Centre than it would in the matter of identifting the organisms concerned. This is necessarily so not only because the International Centre is less immediately preoccupied with epidemiolgical problems than is the National Centre, but also because the detailed
